CPEC Proposed Revisions for Approval of Community College Centers/CPEC

Wednesday, June 30th, 2010

FYI

http://www.cpec.ca.gov/completereports/2009reports/09-08.pdf

“Effective April 1, 2009, a community college off-campus operation that seeks conversion to a state approved educational center must enroll a minimum of 500 annual full-time equivalent students (FTES) during the year immediately preceding the district’s proposal submission.”

“Provisional approval does not involve state capital outlay funds.”

“The 2008 Title 5 regulations authorize the Board of Governors to grant provisional approval to a center if it is to be located in a high population growth area and if an enrollment analysis clearly shows that it would serve 500 FTES annually by the third year of operation.”

Blog:

The proposed Banning outreach campus does not/will not meet the above enrollment criteria now or anytime in the near future. The campus will NOT qualify for state capital outlay funds and/or operating revenue.  It would not meet the criteria for “provisional approval” either for the same reasons.

NO comprehensive enrollment analysis has been done.

Banning Unified balances budget after $3.2 mil in cuts/PE

Tuesday, June 29th, 2010

http://www.pe.com/localnews/stories/PE_News_Local_D_edistrict25.21dff5a.html

“Fourteen classroom positions were eliminated due to a decline in enrollment.”

Blog:

It makes no sense for MSJC to build a college which will have ZERO operating funds in an area experiencing declining enrollments.  Now is not the time to spend $2.6 mil in general fund $$$ on a Banning outreach center.  This is exactly why enrollments studies should be completed before building anything.

Taxpayers beware.

Share This

Posted in News | No Comments »

MSJC to break ground in Banning/Record Gazette

Tuesday, June 29th, 2010

http://www.recordgazette.net/articles/2010/06/29/news/doc4c239f7b66098001683884.txt

“The college is being built out of general funds, since there is no college district facilities bonds, and is being built during an economically challenging time.” Roger Schultz, President

Blog:

The district’s tentative budget, diverts $2.6 mil of general fund $$$ to the capital construction fund for this campus.  That is $2.6 million dollars that should be spent in class offerings at approved campus sites or $2.6 mil to maintain existing facility deficits.

Banning has been planned without enrollment studies.  There are/will be ZERO operating funds because it is not State approved.  To be state approved an outreach center must show enrollments of 500 full-time equivalent students which would require a minimum of 200 sections.  The reality is that budget constraints have forced the district to cancel hundreds of class sections.

The district plans a SFID (School Facility Improvement District) for the November ballot.   Bonds cannot be used for operating expense.  So, where will the operating funds come from?

Share This

Posted in News | No Comments »

Former MSJC police chief pleads guilty/NCTimes - Press Enterprise

Thursday, June 24th, 2010

http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/menifee/article_0d42b4d7-a5fd-528a-b8d9-c34e768811ea.html

http://www.pe.com/localnews/stories/PE_News_Local_D_echief24.d0b28d70.html

“”Segawa and the college are defendants in two lawsuits related to PD operations.  A wrongful termination, breach of contract and defamation case filed by three former probationary police officers and one volunteer reserve officer is pending before the 4th District Court of Appeal.”

“Another case alleging Segawa coerced an employee into resigning under threat of criminal embezzelement charges is pending in Superior Court.”

“The college does not tolerate personnel who violate the law and we are pleased this matter has been resolved.  The college cooperated with the district attorney’s office.”  College Spokeswoman Karin Marriott

Blog:

After the released officer’s formal complaint, the college internal investigation was never released to the BOT.  Segawa was NOT placed on administrative leave until months later, after several presentations to the BOT by the released officers, and after the DA arrived with a search warrant.  It’s unfortunate that administration/BOT did not require an outside investigation when the PD complaints first surfaced well before the DA arrived.  The question, why not?

On several occasions as trustee a request was made for a copy of the district’s investigation.  Response from administration was that the report had been turned over to the DA and was “unavailable”.  It appears that no district investigation was done because witnesses in complaints were never interviewed.  Why not?

Share This

Posted in News | 1 Comment »

Case RIF153582/Defendant-Segawa - Preliminary Hearing

Wednesday, June 23rd, 2010

http://www.riverside.courts.ca.gov/pubacc.htm

“DEFENDANT PLEADS GUILTY TO COUNTS(S) 01-10″

“SPECIFICATION OF PLEA: 365 DAYS COUNTY JAIL LID.”

http://blogs.pe.com/news/digest/2010/06/former-mt-san-jacinto-police-c.html

BLOG:

With a plea of guilty it is interesting that MSJC’s own preliminary investigation found NO wrongdoing by Segawa, while former released probationary officers presented to the board of trustees otherwise.  Also interesting is why the administrator with direct supervision of Segawa was given a positive recommendation for contract renewal by the S/P.  Also interesting is the board of trustee majority members who continued to turn their heads against complaints of officers who were under Segawa’s authority when Chief of PD.

MSJC has been sued by those former officers for wrongful termination.  Segawa was hired by former VP of HR Jon Tyler without a recruitment search through a reorganization of the department.  Not good.
